name: Plant
body: Plants, originally created by the God of Hydrogen Cyanide, were made as a way to define and autonomously war over territory. The first were single-celled fragmentative and propagative, copulating not by seed dispersal but by other less effective means.

successors.name: Algae
successors.body: Amongst the first and simplest of the plants, created to serve as primary producers, spreading territory and creating energy which is used further up in the ecosystem. Algae are capable of surviving and thriving in water environments.

successors.name: Green Algae
successors.body: Amongst the first and simplest of the plants, created to serve as primary producers, spreading territory and creating energy which is used further up in the ecosystem. Algae survive in aquatic environments.

successors.name: Common Green Algae
successors.body: A common algae found in freshwater environments.

successors.name: Brown Algae
successors.body: A common species of freshwater algae which is brown in color.

successors.name: Red Algae
successors.body: An uncommon species of algae which is red in color. During bloom they may turn beaches blood red in color.

successors.name: Diatom
successors.body: A common single-celled algae found in saltwater and freshwater environments.

successors.name: Glowing Algae
successors.body: An uncommon species of algae which are bioluminescent and glow when moved.

successors.name: Golden Algae
successors.body: An uncommon species of freshwater algae which are yellow in color.

successors.name: Pink Algae
successors.body: An uncommon species of freshwater algae used in traditional southern elven medicine. Can be considered to be domesticated by some.

successors.name: Colonial Algae
successors.body: Algae which grow together in colonies.

successors.name: Sea Lettuce
successors.body: Common seaweed found in coastal waters. They have broad leafy fronds.

successors.name: Sphere Algae
successors.body: Common algae found floating on the tops of still water bodies, form spherical clumps.

successors.name: Giant Kelp
successors.body: Common species of kelp which grow in close proximity in shallow waters.

successors.name: Nori
successors.body: Common species of seaweed found in intertidal zones, used in some cuisine.

successors.name: Branching Red Algae
successors.body: Uncommon red seaweeds which appear to branch and grow out similarly to corals. May be used in the production of agar.

successors.name: Worts
successors.body: Created to spread territory in damp terrestrial and subterraneous environments, similar to algae in their purpose.

successors.name: Leafless Worts
successors.body: Created to colonize soils quickly, producing dense mats which protect against erosion.

successors.name: Eastern Mosswort
successors.body: Leafless worts characterized by their flat hair-like growth. Larger than their western cousins.

successors.name: Western Mosswort
successors.body: Leafless worts characterized by their flat hair-like growth. Smaller than their eastern cousins, more brown in color.

successors.name: Red Mosswort
successors.body: Leafless worts characterized by their flat hair-like growth. A deep red in color and found in freshwater environments.

successors.name: Purple Scalewort
successors.body: Leafless worts characterized by their long wavy and scale-like growth pattern. Purple in color and found towards the eastern continents.

successors.name: Scalewort
successors.body: Leafless worts characterized by their long wavy and scale-like growths.

successors.name: Coastal Liverwort
successors.body: Leafless worts with flattened lobed bodies. Found in intertidal zones.

successors.name: Central Liverwort
successors.body: Leafless worts with flattened lobed bodies, found in the jungles of the terrestrial south.

successors.name: Northern Liverwort
successors.body: Leafless worts with flattened lobed bodies, found across the deserts of the coastal north.

successors.name: Hornwort
successors.body: Leafless worts with horn-like structures which protrude from their flat bodies.

successors.name: Giant Hornwort
successors.body: Leafless worts with horn-like structures which protrude from their flat bodies. Found in the central desert of the south, creating large rock-like spikes which protrude from some areas of the desert.

successors.name: Leaved Worts
successors.body: Created to compete with leafless worts, grow slower but create leaves which may steal light from competing smaller plants.

successors.name: Common Green Moss
successors.body: Leaved worts with small leafy shoots which grow densely together, creating hair-like filiment. Found across many of the damp forests of the south and north.

successors.name: Common Yellow Moss
successors.body: Leaved worts with small leafy shoots which grow densely together, creating hair-like filiment. Yellow in color and less common than its green counterpart, found mostly in the north.

successors.name: Pincushion Moss
successors.body: Leaved worts with small leafy shoots which grow densely together, forming hair-like filiment. These moss grow in small spheres, making a pin-cushion like shape.

successors.name: Star Moss
successors.body: Leaved worts with small star-shaped leafy shoots which grow densely together. These star shape is iconic and the center of the star is a deep yellow in color.

successors.name: Leafy Liverwort
successors.body: Leaved worts with small laid-down overlapping leaves arrange in rows.

successors.name: Scalemoss
successors.body: Leaved worts with tiny scale-like leaves which point upwards and form dense mats.

successors.name: Grand Scalemoss
successors.body: Leaved worts with tiny scale-like leaves which lay down and overlap with one another. They may completely cover the trunks of some larger plants, and are even known to overtake some plants in their entirety, starving them.

successors.name: Haircap Moss
successors.body: Leaved worts with long erect brownish-red stems that end in pointed leaves.

successors.name: Common Feather Moss
successors.body: Leaved worts with feather-like soft fronds. Found in many southern forests, especially in damp but not rainy areas.

successors.name: Seminifer
successors.body: An improvement to the previous design, seminifers can spread territory further by procreating with one another.

successors.name: Fern
successors.body: Photosynthetic seminifers which spread by releasing spores into the atmosphere.

successors.name: Common Fiddlehead
successors.body: Ferns characterized by their unfurling leaves and stems. Found throughout much of the southern continent.

successors.name: Pink Fiddlehead
successors.body: Ferns characterized by their unfurling leaves and stems, pink in coloration. Found only in a small portion of the south, where the Great Humid Plane meets the Great Southern Cold Strip.

successors.name: Spiny Shield Fern
successors.body: Ferns which grow broad shield-like hard and spiny fronds to protect it from herbivory. Found on the eastern archipelago and some northwestern islands.

successors.name: Great Shield Fern
successors.body: Large ferns which grow broad shield-like hard and spiny fronds to protect themselves from herbivory. Found on the eastern side of the southern continent.

successors.name: Spiny Fern
successors.body: Ferns with hard waxy spiny fronds made for retaining water. Found in some arid environments across the south.

successors.name: Silver Fern
successors.body: Ferns with silver-tinged fronds, found in some high-altitude regions of the south.

successors.name: Copper Fern
successors.body: Rare species of fern with beautiful orange and red colors across their fronds. Found rarely around the central south mediterranean.

successors.name: Tree Fern
successors.body: Ferns characterized by their tall tree-like structure and large soft fronds. Found in dense rainforests in the south and partially into the north.

successors.name: Horsetail Fern
successors.body: Ferns notable for their segmented stems and radiating branches.

successors.name: Giant Horsetail
successors.body: A large variety of horsetails, they may grow to be multiple meters in height. Rarely found in the south, apparently more common in the north.

successors.name: Common Shrub Fern
successors.body: Ferns with low shrub-like growth patterns.

successors.name: Large Shrub Fern
successors.body: Ferns with low shrub-like growth patterns, may sprawl out over a large area.

successors.name: Mountain Fern
successors.body: Ferns created for high-altitude environments, they have tough leathery fronds.

successors.name: Desert Fern
successors.body: Ferns created to survive arid environments, they sport waxy fronds and thick reduced leaves. Very common across the islands connecting the north and south.

successors.name: Bog Fern
successors.body: Ferns created for acidic nutrient-poor environments like bogs and peatland. Found across much of the souths coast.

successors.name: River Fern
successors.body: Aquatic ferns with tall stems which reach up to the surface of the water and long soft leaves which float on the surface.

successors.name: Saltwater Fern
successors.body: Aquatic ferns found on brackish and saltwater coasts, usually amongst mangroves in shaded areas.

successors.name: Fungus
successors.body: Seminifers which spread by releasing spores into the atmosphere. Attain their nutrience by consuming biotic material.

successors.name: Mold
successors.body: Fungus created to quickly break down organic matter.

successors.name: Yeast
successors.body: Fungus created to aid in fermentation, thriving in anaerobic environments where fermentation is vital.

successors.name: Shroom
successors.body: Fungus created to hold symbiotic relationshipos with plants.

successors.name: Gill-less Shrooms
successors.body: Adapted for environments where spore dispersal is more challenging, relying on other methods.

successors.name: Gilled Shrooms
successors.body: Adapted for environments where spore dispersal is easiest, allowing them to thrive in forest and dense habitats.

successors.name: Florifer
successors.body: Seminifers which spread by convincing other species to spread their seed.

successors.name: Conifers
successors.body: Florifiers which produce seed-bearing cones which can spread seeds autonomously by wind.

successors.name: Redwoods
successors.body: Some of the largest trees in the world.

successors.name: Chimetrees
successors.body: Nutty conifers found in dry climates. Produce elongated woody wind chime-like cones.

successors.name: Fruiting Plants
successors.body: Florifers which produce fleshy fruits to attract organisms which may spread their seeds.

successors.name: Aquatic
successors.body: Fruiting plants created to thrive in primarily aquatic environments.

successors.name: Rice
successors.body: Monsoon and humid subtropical plant.

successors.name: Arboreal
successors.body: Fruiting plants created with thick woody stems to protect them from trampling, foraging, and consumption.

successors.name: Date Palm
successors.body: Desert climate plant.

successors.name: Baobab
successors.body: Savannah climate plant.

successors.name: Beech
successors.body: Oceanic climate plant.

successors.name: Cocoa Tree
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant. Their seeds may be dried and crushed to make chocolate.

successors.name: Fig Tree
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Maple
successors.body: Humid continental plant.

successors.name: Olive
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Pecan Tree
successors.body: Humid subtropical climate plant.

successors.name: Rubber Tree
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant. Their tree sap may be dried and hardened into organic rubber.

successors.name: Shea Tree
successors.body: Savannah climate plant.

successors.name: Teak
successors.body: Monsoon climate plant.

successors.name: Almond
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Apple
successors.body: Humid continental climate plant.

successors.name: Cherry
successors.body: Humid continental climate plants.

successors.name: Citron
successors.body: Humid subtropical climate plant.

successors.name: Mandarin Orange
successors.body: Humid subtropical climate plant.

successors.name: Lemon
successors.body: Hybrid plant which grows in Mediterranean climates.

successors.name: Curry Tree
successors.body: Monsoon climate plant.

successors.name: Papaya
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant.

successors.name: Herbaceous
successors.body: Fruiting plants created with thin soft stems.

successors.name: Agave
successors.body: Desert climate plant.

successors.name: Aloe
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Barley
successors.body: Cold desert and cold steppe climate plant.

successors.name: Buckwheat
successors.body: Subarctic continental climate plant.

successors.name: Carrot
successors.body: Subarctic continental climate plant.

successors.name: Chamomile
successors.body: Humid continental climate plants.

successors.name: Ginger
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant.

successors.name: Millet
successors.body: Savannah climate plant.

successors.name: Oat
successors.body: Humid continental plant.

successors.name: Pineapple
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant.

successors.name: Potato
successors.body: Subarctic continental climate plant.

successors.name: Sage
successors.body: Cold desert climate plant.

successors.name: Yams
successors.body: Savannah climate plant.

successors.name: Climbing
successors.body: Fruiting plants which creep up as they grow, climbing and trailing other structures.

successors.name: Yellow Bamboo
successors.body: Monsoon climate plant.

successors.name: Cavendish Banana
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant.

successors.name: Black Cardamom
successors.body: Monsoon climate plant.

successors.name: Green Cardamom
successors.body: Monsoon climate plant.

successors.name: Turmeric
successors.body: Monsoon climate plant.

successors.name: Vanilla
successors.body: Rainforest climate plant.

successors.name: Table Grape
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Spear Mint
successors.body: Humid continental plant.

successors.name: Oregano
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Prickly Pear
successors.body: Desert climate plant.

successors.name: Rosemary
successors.body: Mediterranean climate plant.

successors.name: Animal
successors.body: Seminifers which spread their territory by autonomous movement. Such a move necessitated the creation of new organelles, cell communication methods, and skeletal systems.

successors.name: Vermin
successors.body: Ancestor created to function in moist subterraneous and aquatic environments, for this reason they have simple soft unspecialized bodies.

successors.name: Worm
successors.body: Vermins created with no external manipulable limbs. Move by contracting their bodies.

successors.name: Gastropod
successors.body: Vermins characterized by their mobility using a single muscular foot at the bottom of their body.

successors.name: Slug
successors.body: Shell-less gastropods.

successors.name: Snail
successors.body: Gastropods created to develop and grow shells to protect them from predators.

successors.name: Cephalopods
successors.body: Created to function in highly moist and aquatic environments, very intelligent and partially sociable, leading to the advent of their tentacles.

successors.name: Bivalves
successors.body: Ancestor created to function primarily in aquatic and moist terrestrial environments, build external shell structures to protect organs.

successors.name: Arthropods
successors.body: Ancestor created to function in terrestrial and aquatic environments, their size necessitated the creation of exoskeletal carapace which must molt to grow.

successors.name: Crustacea
successors.body: Arthropods characterized by their biramous appendages.

successors.name: Copepod
successors.body: Crustacea differentiated by their small tear-shaped bodies.

successors.name: Shrimp
successors.body: Often small exclusively aquatic crustacean with specialized swimming tails and fused heads and thorax.

successors.name: Crab
successors.body: Crustacea with a short, tucked, sometimes abscent tail.

successors.name: Lobster
successors.body: Crustacea possessing claws on their first three pair of limbs, often with a enlarged first pair.

successors.name: Hexapod
successors.body: Athropods characterized by their uniraamous appendages.

successors.name: Wingless Insects
successors.body: Hexapods characterized by the absence of wings. Created for a variety of niches.

successors.name: Mites
successors.body: Small, often parasitic, wingless insects.

successors.name: Common Flea
successors.body: The common flea, found in a majority of abodes. Known for their parasitizing of the domestic bear and cat.

successors.name: Coastal Avian Flea
successors.body: Fleas found across the coastal jungles of the north and south, parasitizing birds and bats.

successors.name: Dragon Flea
successors.body: Flea known for parasitizing bats, primarily species of dragon.

successors.name: Myriapod
successors.body: Wingless insects characterized by their long segmented bodies, each segment with a pair of legs.

successors.name: Spiders
successors.body: Wingless insects with specialized abdomens capable of producing silk.

successors.name: Scorpion
successors.body: Wingless insects characterized by their segmented curved tail ending in a stinging appendage.

successors.name: Winged Insects
successors.body: Hexapods characterized by the presence of wings. Created for atmospheric purposes.

successors.name: Metamorphosing Insects
successors.body: Insects characterized by their undergoing of the process of metamorphosis.

successors.name: Flies
successors.body: Insects characterized by their small sizes.

successors.name: Lepidoptera
successors.body: Insects characterized by their large scaly-wings and extremely mobile larval stage.

successors.name: Starmoth
successors.body: Moths which lay dormant across much of the Plane. When a star falls heaps of these moth emmerge from the ground to follow the star, consuming mythril which forms around it. In the modern day they are close to extinction.

successors.name: Domestic Silkmoth
successors.body: Moths domesticated in the eastern archipelago by the dwarves. Their cocoons may be spun into fine thread.

successors.name: Colonial Insects
successors.body: Insects characterized by their complex social structures, often consisting of a queen and drones. Although not all species are social.

successors.name: Ants
successors.body: Colonial insects characterized by their distinct worker, soldier, and queen castes.

successors.name: Medicine Ants
successors.body: A species of ant found in the western mediterranean. Used in medicine to clean wounds. Years of use have led to some 'domestic' varities.

successors.name: Bees
successors.body: Colonial insects characterized by their role in pollinating, known for their production of honey and wax.

successors.name: Domestic Sextown Bee
successors.body: Domestic species of bee native to the sextown region of the world.

successors.name: Domestic Northern Bee
successors.body: Domestic species of bee native to the nothern continent.

successors.name: Domestic Southwestern Bee
successors.body: Domestic species of bee native to the southern continent.

successors.name: Domestic Giant Bee
successors.body: Domestic species of bee native to the eastern archipelago.

successors.name: Wasps
successors.body: Colonial insects characterized by their predatory or parasitic behavior and slender bodies.

successors.name: Beetles
successors.body: Insects whos front wings have hardened into a protective covering.

successors.name: Weevil
successors.body: Beetles distinguished by their elongated snout for boring and herbivorous diets.

successors.name: Longhorn Beetles
successors.body: Beetles characterized by their long antennae and boring larvae.

successors.name: Leaf Beetles
successors.body: Beetles characterized by their herbivorous diets and diverse colorful patterns.

successors.name: Scarab Beetles
successors.body: Beetles characterized by their clubbed antennae, stout bodies, and diverse diets.

successors.name: Ground Beetles
successors.body: Beetles characterized by their long tails, powerful mandibles, and predatory behavior.

successors.name: Tiger Beetles
successors.body: Beetles characterized by their large eyes, prominent mandibles, fast speed, and predatory behavior.

successors.name: Diving Beetles
successors.body: Beetles characterized by their aquatic behavior, streamlined bodies, and flattened swimming legs.

successors.name: Incomplete-metamorphosing Insects
successors.body: Insects characterized by the absence of metamorphosis in their development.

successors.name: True Flies
successors.body: Insects characterized by their one pair of wings.

successors.name: Flatbugs
successors.body: Insects characterized by their flattened bodies. Omnivores and predators.

successors.name: Earwigs
successors.body: Omnivorous flatbugs characterized by their pincer-like cerci.

successors.name: Roaches
successors.body: Flatbug with segmented antennae, flat bodies, and omnivorous behavior.

successors.name: Termites
successors.body: Flatbug characterized by their social colonies with distinct clastes of workers. Known for their woody apetite.

successors.name: Hoppers
successors.body: Insects characterized by their strong hind legs and herbivorous or predatory behavior.

successors.name: Grasshopper
successors.body: Hoppers known for their jumping and loud sounds.

successors.name: Cricket
successors.body: Hoppers known for their characteristic chirping.

successors.name: Katydid
successors.body: Large hoppers known for their camouflage and loud continous calls.

successors.name: Scythebugs
successors.body: Insects characterized by their elongated bodies and scythe-like forelimbs.

successors.name: Stickbug
successors.body: Scythebugs known for their elongated camouflaged bodies.

successors.name: Mantis
successors.body: ory scythebugs known for their ambush behavior and praying-like stance.

successors.name: Predatory Flies
successors.body: Insects characterized by their elongated bodies and predatory behavior.

successors.name: Damselfly
successors.body: Narrow-bodied predatory flies which hold their wings against their body when at rest.

successors.name: Dragonfly
successors.body: Slender and long-bodied predatory flies which hold their wings horizontal to their bodies when at rest.

successors.name: Beaked Insects
successors.body: Insects characterized by their beak-like mouth parts.

successors.name: Cicada
successors.body: Beaked insects known for their loud buzzing calls, spend much of their lifecycle buried beneath the soil as nymphs.

successors.name: Aphid
successors.body: Small soft-bodied herbivorous beaked insects known for sitting on and feeding off of sappy plants.

successors.name: Leafhopper
successors.body: Wedge-shaped beaked insects known for their elongated hing legs made for jumping.

successors.name: Vertebrate
successors.body: Ancestor created to function in aquatic environments and grow larger in size, necessitating the creation of the spine.

successors.name: Carilaginous Fish
successors.body: Vertebrate which do not have completely ossified bone structure.

successors.name: Rays
successors.body: Cartilaginous fish with flattened bodies and enlarged pectoral fins.

successors.name: Sharks
successors.body: Cartilaginous fish characterized by their pectoral fins that are not fused to their heads.

successors.name: Jawless Fish
successors.body: As the need for larger, more powerful, or more agile bodies arised vertebrate were created with ossified bone structures but lacked manipulable jaws.

successors.name: Armored Jawless Fish
successors.body: Jawless fish with hard bone-like scales.

successors.name: Jawless Eels
successors.body: Jawless fish with soft elongated eel-like bodies.

successors.name: Bony Fish
successors.body: When jawless vertebrates were no longer powerful enough vertebrate with completely ossified skeletal structure and bony jaws were created.

successors.name: Ray-finned Fish
successors.body: Bony fish with fins made of webbed bony spines.

successors.name: Lobe-finned Fish
successors.body: Bony fish with muscular lobed fins supported by articulated skeletal structure.

successors.name: Amphibia
successors.body: Vertebrate created for terrestrial mobility, have modified ovaries for laying eggs.

successors.name: Salamanders
successors.body: Amphibia created with powerful back legs for leaping and swimming, created to hunt insects.

successors.name: Frogs
successors.body: Small amphibia created to hunt invertebrates.

successors.name: Mega Amphibia
successors.body: Amphibia created to fulfil tertiary ranks in the ecosystem. Large and powerful, created for hunting.

successors.name: Synapsids
successors.body: Synapsids marked the move to complete terrestrial lives, requiring the loss of moist eggs and a move to hard shelled protective eggs.

successors.name: Reptilia
successors.body: Created to be quicker, more agile, and more powerful than their synapsid ancestors.

successors.name: Squamata
successors.body: Generally smaller and more agile reptiles created primarily for predatory reasons.

successors.name: Lizards
successors.body: Squamata characterized by their presence of legs.

successors.name: Snakes
successors.body: Lizards characterized by their absence of limbs.

successors.name: Turtles
successors.body: Larger and more armored reptiles created to serve primarily herbivorous niches in their ecosystems.

successors.name: Archosaurs
successors.body: Typically large and powerful reptiles created for a variety of environments and reasons.

successors.name: Crocodylomorphs
successors.body: Archosaurs which use little energy and are adapted for moist wet environments.

successors.name: Dinosauria
successors.body: The largest of the archosaurs, their large bodies requiring specialized pelvic bones.

successors.name: Therapod
successors.body: Dinosauria created for primarily carnivorous and tertiary niches.

successors.name: Sauropod
successors.body: Dinosauria created primarily for herbivorous and consumptive niches.

successors.name: Aves
successors.body: Small and nimble archosaurs created to fill a variety of ecosystems and environments.

successors.name: Perching Birds
successors.body: Birds characterized by their small-to-medium sizes and perching feet.

successors.name: Waterfowl
successors.body: Birds characterized by their webbed feet and typically flat beaks.

successors.name: Columbiforms
successors.body: Birds characterized by their small stout bodies.

successors.name: Parrots
successors.body: Birds characterized by their grasping feet, curved bills, and exotic colors.

successors.name: Birds of Prey
successors.body: Birds characterized by their large sizes, hooked beaks, and taloned feet.

successors.name: Swifts
successors.body: Birds characterized by their small bodies and agile flying abilities.

successors.name: Mammalia
successors.body: Created to carry and nurture young to ensure they survive longer. Created with placenta made to carry young and have mammary glands to produce milk for young.

successors.name: Marsupial
successors.body: Mammals which give birth to undeveloped young and use extra time and resources to nurture them outside of the womb.

successors.name: Marsupial Bears
successors.body: Created to fulfil predatory niches in the ecosystem.

successors.name: Wombat
successors.body: Marsupial bears with short stuby bodies.

successors.name: Sugar Glider
successors.body: Small marsupial bears with wing-like membranes connecting their hind and forelimbs.

successors.name: Marsupial Shrews
successors.body: Created to fulfil herbivorous niches in the ecosystem.

successors.name: Northern Kangaroo
successors.body: Large marsupial shrews, found across much of the north western deserts. Characterized by their powerful hindlimbs and tails built for powerful hops and kicks. They can be differentiated from their northern counterparts by their dull tan color and more stiff ears.

successors.name: Eastern Kangaroo
successors.body: Large marsupial shrews, created following the Northern Kangaroo species. Much like their relatives, characterized by their powerful hindlimbs and tails built for hopping and kicking. Eastern kangaroos may also be differentiated by their longer tails, less stiff ears, and red color.

successors.name: Giant Kangaroo
successors.body: Created following the success of the Northern Kangaroo. Giant Kangaroo are rare in the modern day, found only in select regions of the great southern deserts. Giant Kangaroo like their relatives are characterized by their hunched postures and powerful hindlimbs and tails, made for powerful hops and kicks. Some members of this species may stand to be over 2 meters in height and are often a dull tan across much of their body, although males have blue and yellow splotches across their bellies and tails.

successors.name: Western Possum
successors.body: Mid-sized gray and black rat-like marsupial shrews.

successors.name: Opposum
successors.body: Mid-sized gray and black rat-like marsupial shrews.

successors.name: Placentalia
successors.body: Mammals which give birth to fully nourished offspring.

successors.name: Rodents
successors.body: Often small fingered mammals with diverse ecological roles.

successors.name: Shrews
successors.body: Small insectivorous terrestrial placentalia.

successors.name: Moles
successors.body: Placentalia with large claws, often for subterraneous digging.

successors.name: Lagomorphs
successors.body: Placentalia whose incisors continuously grow.

successors.name: Armored Mammals
successors.body: Placentalia with prominent armor-like coverings.

successors.name: Primates
successors.body: Placentalia with apposable thumbs.

successors.name: Long-tailed Primates
successors.body: Primates which posses elongated posable tails.

successors.name: Short-tailed Primates
successors.body: Primates which posses short stubby tails.

successors.name: Bats
successors.body: Placentalia created with wing-like hands capable of flight.

successors.name: Megabat
successors.body: Bats characterized by their larger sizes and often herbivorous diets.

successors.name: Microbat
successors.body: Bats characterized by their smaller sizes and often carnivorous diets.

successors.name: Insectivorous Microbat
successors.body: Microbats characterized by their insectivorous diets.

successors.name: Vampire Bat
successors.body: Microbats characterized by their carnivorous diets consisting of blood.

successors.name: Nectar Microbat
successors.body: Microbats characterized by their diets consisting of fruits, nectar, and pollen.

successors.name: Dragon
successors.body: Bats characterized by their ability to walk on their wings and large sizes.

successors.name: Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Greater dragons characterized by their small sizes.

successors.name: Elf Root Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmy dragons today only found in the north. They are known to congregate around elder elves.

successors.name: Moss Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Green and lime green pigmy dragons found in many of the southern tropics.

successors.name: Northeastern Long-tailed Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmy dragons found in

successors.name: Western Travelers Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmy dragons found across most of the western tropics. Known to follow travelers for their food.

successors.name: Boreal Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmy dragons found in the boreal forests of the south.

successors.name: Domestic Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Domesticated pigmy dragon.

successors.name: Great Lake Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmies found across the great lakes of the north.

successors.name: Mountain Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmies found throughout many of the mountains of the south.

successors.name: Eastern Tropical Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmies found in the eastern archipelago tropics.

successors.name: Neotropical Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmies found across the souths neotropics.

successors.name: Long-tailed Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmy dragons with long tails, found in the south.

successors.name: Yellow Cup-footed Dragon
successors.body: Cup-footed dragon found throughout much of the southern desert.

successors.name: Northern Tropic Cup-footed Dragon
successors.body: Cup-footed dragon found in the tropics of the north.

successors.name: Northern Tropic Pigmy Dragon
successors.body: Pigmy dragons found in the northern tropic forests.

successors.name: Greater Leaf-nosed Dragon
successors.body: Leaf-nosed dragons found across much of the norths east.

successors.name: Leaf-nosed Dragon
successors.body: Small leaf-nosed dragons found in the souths forests.

successors.name: Horned Dragon
successors.body: Greater dragons characterized by their horn-like protrusions from their heads.

successors.name: Archipelago Horseshoe Dragon
successors.body: Small dragons with U-shaped horns found acorss many of the island chains across the plane.

successors.name: Eastern Buffalo Dragon
successors.body: Found in the eastern archipelago, mid-sized bulky dragons with buffalo-like horns.

successors.name: New World Grand Dragon
successors.body: Large horned dragon found in the north with elk-like racks.

successors.name: Western Boreal Dragon
successors.body: Dragon found in the western parts of the south. Has V-shaped parting horns.

successors.name: New World Jungle Dragon
successors.body: Dragon found in the north with a large single curved horn on its head.

successors.name: Ornamental Dragon
successors.body: Horned dragon found in the north with large fan-like horn across its head.

successors.name: Bulldog Dragon
successors.body: Greater dragons characterized by their short stubby bulldog-like snouts.

successors.name: Lesser Fishing Dragon
successors.body: Lesser bulldog dragons found at the souths great lakes.

successors.name: Fishing Dragon
successors.body: Mid-sized basking dragon found across the coast of much of the northern continent.

successors.name: Pigmy Fishing Dragon
successors.body: Lesser bulldog dragons found across much of the souths coasts.

successors.name: Eastern Basking Dragon
successors.body: Small bulldog dragon found throughout the eastern archipelago's islands.

successors.name: Lesser Pigmy Basking Dragon
successors.body: Lesser bulldog dragon found in the souths boreal forests.

successors.name: Southern Basking Dragon
successors.body: Mid-sized bulldog dragon found throughout much of the southern continents mountains.

successors.name: Red Basking Dragon
successors.body: Large bulldog dragon found throughout much of the great southern deserts.

successors.name: Pigmy Basking Dragon
successors.body: The smallest of the bulldog dragons.

successors.name: Devil Dragon
successors.body: Greater dragons characterized by their large sizes.

successors.name: Polar Dragon
successors.body: True devil dragons which use their spells to keep their bodies warm, allowing them to live in the north and easts polar climates.

successors.name: Great Angel Dragon
successors.body: Large true devil dragons with eye-like spots across their wings.

successors.name: Lesser Red Dragon
successors.body: A small true devil dragon red and brown in color.

successors.name: Great Wheezing Dragon
successors.body: True devil dragon characterized by their large size and wheezing-like sound produced when casting some spells.

successors.name: False Red Dragon
successors.body: False devil dragons which attempt to mimic adult lesser red dragons.

successors.name: False Angel Dragon
successors.body: False devil dragons which attempt to mimic adolescent great angel dragons.

successors.name: Borborygamous Dragon
successors.body: True devil dragon characterized by their absolutely massive size and large bulging neck folds.

successors.name: False Borborygamous Dragon
successors.body: Large false devil dragons which attempt to mimic adolescent borborygamous dragons.

successors.name: Whip-tailed Dragon
successors.body: Lesser dragons characterized by their long slender tails which can be used like whips.

successors.name: Eastern Whip-tail
successors.body: Large whip-tailed dragon found across the eastern deserts of the north.

successors.name: Northern Mega Whip-tail
successors.body: Large whip-tailed dragons found across much of the norths mountains.

successors.name: Southern Black Whip-tail
successors.body: Black whip-tailed dragons found across small portions of the souths deserts.

successors.name: Tropical Pigmy Whip-tail
successors.body: Small whip-tailed dragons found in the eastern desert of the north.

successors.name: Carnivora
successors.body: Mammals with primarily carnivorous diets and diverse hunting practices.

successors.name: Caniforms
successors.body: Carnivora with nonretractable claws.

successors.name: Canids
successors.body: Mid-sized caniforms known for their social behaviors.

successors.name: Ursus
successors.body: Large stocky short-tailed primarily omnivorous caniforms.

successors.name: Mask Bear
successors.body: Highly specialized bear created to hunt Organisms of Mass Destruction. Today only found in the north, hunting what few OMD still live.

successors.name: Giant Panda
successors.body: Specialized herbivorous bears created by a northern God. Today only found on the Northern Island Chain.

successors.name: Sloth Bear
successors.body: Short-faced bears which get their names from their lanky and long-clawed sloth-like appearence.

successors.name: Sun Bear
successors.body: Short-faced bears which get their names from the yellow-colored spot on their chests.

successors.name: Ghost Bear
successors.body: Large white or gray short-faced bears found around the oceanic deserts of the north and south.

successors.name: Brown Bear
successors.body: Native to the northern continent, created to hunt relatively large prey.

successors.name: Northern Black Bear
successors.body: Created by a northern God with the objective of hunting large prey to defend their territory.

successors.name: Southern Black Bear
successors.body: Following the creation of the Northern Black Bear the Southern Black Bear would be created with some minor anatomical differences.

successors.name: Domestic Dog-bear
successors.body: The domesticated Dog-bear, found across many households of the south.

successors.name: Mustiforms
successors.body: Small caniforms characterized by their elongated slender bodies and musty scent glands.

successors.name: Feliforms
successors.body: Carnivora with retractable claws.

successors.name: Cetacea
successors.body: Often large mammals adapted for marine environments.

successors.name: Seals
successors.body: Cetacea characterized by their terrestrial behavior.

successors.name: Whales
successors.body: Completely aquatic cetacea characterized by their large size and filter-feeding diets.

successors.name: Dolphins
successors.body: Completely aquatic cetacea characterized by their smaller sizes.

successors.name: Ungulates
successors.body: Mammals with hooves.

successors.name: Even-toed Ungulates
successors.body: Ungulates with an even number of toes.

successors.name: Cattle
successors.body: Even-toed ungulates characterized by their sturdy builds and horns.

successors.name: Cervidae
successors.body: Even-toed ungulates characterized by their slender and tall bodies created for running. Often accompanied by antlers.

successors.name: Common Deer
successors.body: The first of the cervids, and the basal form of deer.

successors.name: Common Moose
successors.body: Tall, powerful, and lanky cervids. Characterized by their large and flat antlers and stocky face. Found in the wilds of the southern cold climates.

successors.name: Wrinkled Deer
successors.body: A small wrinkly species of solitary deer found across islands in the oceanic southern crater scape. Males and females grow short, straight, spined antlers.

successors.name: Northern Moose
successors.body: Relatives of the common moose, tall powerful and lanky. Found across cold northern climates.

successors.name: Blue Forest Deer
successors.body: A mid-sized rare species of deer, dark deep blue in color. Antlers are found only in males and grow like

successors.name: Pigmy Moose
successors.body: Small species of moose, sharing the characteristic lanky legs and powerful necks. Amongst the cervids pigmy moose have some of the largest antlers compared to body size. Found across the grasslands of the south and east.

successors.name: Mage's Deer
successors.body: A rare species of deer capable of casting spells, found in warmer climates in the southwest of the plane.

successors.name: Domestic Moose
successors.body: A smaller species of moose created to service humans as powerful and quick steeds. Their smaller bodies are more well adapted for warmer and hotter climates, making them more versatile for different climates.

successors.name: Sus
successors.body: Even-toed ungulates characterized by their often omnivorous diets and short stout bodies.

successors.name: Giraffe
successors.body: Even-toed ungulates characterized by their herbivorous diets and often tall lanky builds, created for foraging high foliage.

successors.name: Amber Giraffe
successors.body: The first of the giraffes. Extinct in the present, they gained their name from their amber orange color. Short and stout, similar to the Okapi of the modern day.

successors.name: Horseshoe Giraffe
successors.body: Giraffes characterized by the u-shaped horns adorned upon their head. Horseshoe giraffes have long necks and legs alongside dark brown bodies. Common in monsoon climates in the south and east.

successors.name: Shielded Giraffe
successors.body: Giraffes characterized by the leaf-shaped flat horns which create a shield-like pattern above their head. Shielded giraffe have relatively long legs and necks. Today they are nearly extinct and found rarely in some savannahs in the northwest.

successors.name: Horned Giraffe
successors.body: Giraffes characterized by their sharp jagged horns. Horned giraffes have short legs but relatively long necks, amongst the smaller species of giraffe. Found in continental climates in the north.

successors.name: Dome-headed Giraffe
successors.body: Giraffes characterized by the thick and hard dome on the top of their cranium. Used for mating displays where males will whip their heads into each others skulls. Short and stubby giraffes with tan bodies and dark brown spots. Found across many savannahs in the north and south.

successors.name: Spotted Giraffe
successors.body: The common image of a giraffe, tall neck and long legs. Pale tan bodies covered in dark and light brown spots. Found across many savannahs of the north and south.

successors.name: White Giraffe
successors.body: Shorter than their spotted relatives, white giraffes are primarily white and tan in coloration with dark and light brown heads. Found across savannahs of the north.

successors.name: Pigmy Giraffe
successors.body: Giraffes characterized by their very small size, with the largest individuals standing no more than half a meter in height. Brown in color, they are found across isolated savannah climates in the east.

successors.name: Okapi
successors.body: Giraffes characterized by their black and while coloration and short stature. Found across temperate rainforests in the north.

successors.name: Camelidae
successors.body: Even-toed ungulates characterized by their long necks and legs, thick coats, and fat reserves.

successors.name: Odd-toed Ungulates
successors.body: Ungulates with an odd number of toes.

successors.name: Equidae
successors.body: Odd-toed ungulates characterized by their herbivorous diets, slender legs and bodies, and social behavior.

successors.name: Rhino
successors.body: Odd-toed ungulates characterized by their heavy bodies covered in thick armored skin. Distinguished by their large horns.

successors.name: Tapir
successors.body: Odd-toed ungulates characterized by their trunk-like snouts and herbivorous diets.

successors.name: Chalicotheri
successors.body: Odd-toed ungulates characterized by their clawed feet and elongated legs.
